According to the release notes, from now on aria2 should look for aria2.conf in $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/aria2/ and for dht.dat in $XDG_CACHE_HOME/aria2/, but that's still not quite the case. The program does indeed look for aria2.conf in the XDG directory, but dht.dat is still being searched for only in the old config dir, $HOME/.aria2, even though I moved it into $XDG_CACHE_HOME/aria2/, where it seems not to be able to find it.

title: Add option to ignore output file name for metalink
body:
It will be very useful for scripts. For example, I have string like this in my `/etc/makepkg.conf` on ArchLinux: `'http::/usr/bin/aria2c %u -o %o -s16 -x16'`. And it's very problematic to download files from download.gnome.org since they are use metalinks. aria2c just saves metalink with name supplied by `-o` option. I'm willing to propose some kind of `--ignore-explicit-name-if-metalink`. 

Or please advice me some option (e.g. modify UA) to force server to return file instead of metalink.

title: Redquest: GlobalStats console progress info without rpc
body:
From the console, when using with `--show-console-readout`, instead of seeing

```
[DL:1.1MiB][#12af8c 240KiB/445KiB(53%)][#004f39 96KiB/179KiB(53%)][#27028a 80KiB/126KiB(63%)][#47a5da 16KiB/211KiB(7%)][#f1ced9 0B/0B]
```

I'd like to see something like this...

```
[ downloadSpeed : uploadSpeed ] [ active : stopped : waiting ] [DL: ]
```

If a `--console-readout-format` existed where one could build the output desired ( "Elapsed: %t Completed: %S of %T Avg Down: %d Up: %u" ) that'd be great. But just having the GlobalStat available on the console output without extra calls or hassle would be useful.

title: custom jsonrpc path
body:
Would be great if you may a choose rpc path like ws://10.0.0.1:6800/mycustomjsonrpc
Its almost impossible to run mutliple jsonrpc services with /jsonrpc path on same SSL Proxy

So this proxypass would not work.

```
    ProxyPass /jsonrpc ws://127.0.0.1:9090/jsonrpc
    ProxyPassReverse /jsonrpc ws://127.0.0.1:9090/jsonrpc
    ProxyPass /jsonrpc ws://127.0.0.1:6800/jsonrpc  
    ProxyPassReverse /jsonrpc ws://127.0.0.1:6800/jsonrpc
```

Thanks

title: HTTPS unavailable on Android 4.0+
body:
The CA certificates shipped with Android are stored in separated files in `/etc/security/cacerts/`, however aria2c supports only one CA certificate file. I'm not sure whether any single file of them is in PEM format and thus can be recognized by aria2.

Is it legal to bundle some CA certificates with aria2 distribution? Thence this problem would be certainly solved. Thank you very much!

title: An extension of Firefox for aria2
body: Nowadays, many download actions are web browsers driven. Therefore, an integration of aria2 in web browsers is very necessary. Up to now,  there does not exist a good one. Though [Flashgot](https://flashgot.net/) is that one, it only supports single task. For example, if I want to download seven files in a webpage with [Flashgot](https://flashgot.net/)+aria2, then seven aria2c processes will run. This is unacceptable in a desktop environment, [Flashgot](https://flashgot.net/) does not make use of the adding URIs feature of RPC. Another shortcoming of [Flashgot](https://flashgot.net/) is that it does not support downloading all files in a webpage with aria2, certainly, file type filter is more impossible. Thus, could somebody create an extension of Firefox for aria2 to overcome these shortcomings? It is better that if this extension can support the set of download path, because we always need to download files to different directories.

title: Non-ASCII character support in Content-Disposition header
body: When iterating over Content-Disposition header, file names are processed byte by byte, so wide characters often (if not always) trigger early parsing quit.

title: --max-download-limit=<SPEED> and --max-overall-download-limit=<SPEED>
body:
Hi Tatsuhiro,

For HTTP/FTP/SFTP Options, the speed control options are less than those for BitTorrent Specific Options.  Say, I can find the following things for comparison:

   HTTP/FTP/SFTP Options
   --lowest-speed-limit=<SPEED>

  BitTorrent Specific Options
  --bt-request-peer-speed-limit=<SPEED>
  --max-overall-upload-limit=<SPEED>
  -u, --max-upload-limit=<SPEED>

But, I also find the following options in the `advanced Options' section form the manual:

```
--max-overall-download-limit=<SPEED>
--max-download-limit=<SPEED>
```

About these two `advanced Options', I've the following questions want to be cleared out:

[1]  Are these two options effective all of the  HTTP(S)/FTP  /SFTP  and  BitTorrent downloadings?

[2]  Are these two options based on the per each download and all of the downloading items instead of per each connction to do the speed conrolling?

[3] Why not also give the following two options:

```
 --min-overall-download-limit=<SPEED>
 --min-download-limit=<SPEED>
```

If so, the speed control can be done in more aspects.

Regards

wget -r -p -np -k http://xxx.com/abc/

title: Limit number of simultaneously used uris per one connection
body:
Hello.
It seems that now aria2 can open N http/ftp connections for every download. If it has >N uris for the download, it will choose N uris, if it has less, it can open more than one connection to one uri. I would need aria2 to behave this way: Choose one uri from the list and open N connection to it. If download fails, then open N connections to another uri from the list. Is it possible to force aria2 to act this way now or would it give sense to add such functionality to aria2?

title: About the speed used in the aria2c: is the limit/result  based on per connection or per server?
body:

dl_speed, sc_avg_speed, mc_avg_speed 

and

--lowest-speed-limit

But, I want to know the following things about the speed evaluation standand, I mean,  are these speed limits/results  based on per connection of specific server or the total speed of per server which taken all the connections to the server into accounted?

Regards

title: Which completedLength will be used by the resume?
body:
Hi Tatsuhiro,

In the manual, I can read the following descriptions:

```
aria2.getFiles([secret], gid)
 [snip]
              completedLength
                 Completed length of this file in bytes.  Please note that
                 it  is  possible that sum of completedLength is less than
                 the completedLength returned  by  the  aria2.tellStatus()
                 method.     This    is    because    completedLength   in
                 aria2.getFiles() only includes completed pieces.  On  the
                 other  hand,  completedLength  in aria2.tellStatus() also
                 includes partially completed pieces.
```

So, which completedLength will be used by the resume method based *.aria2?  From the log file, it seems that, somtimes, some partially completed pieces are discarded, sometimes are used for resuming the downloading.

Regards

body:
Hi Tatsuhiro,

I've the following idea:

I've a lot of uris of the Debian mirror site, if I can obtian the Server Performance Profile for all of them before the downloading, then the subsequent downloading will be more efficient based on the pre-made Server Performance Profile.

For the above purpose, I first make a input-file which including the following contents ( thtere are 324 lines in it totally):

  ftp://artfiles.org/debian/dists/jessie/main/installer-amd64/current/images/hd-media/boot.img.gz
ftp://buaya.klas.or.id/debian/dists/jessie/main/installer-amd64/current/images/hd-media/boot.img.gz

Then I use the following command to obtain the Server Performance Profile for all of these servers:

Then, after 60 seconds, I will obtain the Server Performance Profile for all of these servers which stored in the file named server-stat.log.

But, I'm not so sure about the correctness/accuracy on the Server Performance Profile obtained by the above method.  Any hints/suggestions on my above idea?

title: Conform to PEP 394
body:
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0394/

More specifically, running mkapiref.py fails on an Archlinux system as the hashbang points to python which points to Python 3 instead of Python 2 on it and errors out as print is no longer a statement.

I can think of two ways of solving this. The easy way would be using python2 instead which should work on every platform worth supporting. The slightly harder way would be making the script work for both Python 2 and 3 which is simple enough, just insert `from __future__ import print` at the top and turn all print statements into function calls by using parentheses around the arguments (an empty string as argument can be just omitted). That way would work for all currently supported Python 2 versions (which would be 2.6 and 2.7).

Which of the two options do you prefer?

Say, for example, the above one I mentioned here, I think it should mean that _one_ aria2c command will construct only _one_  `queue` for downloading, and each downloading file is a item of this `queue`.  Am I right or not?

title: Maybe memory leak
body:
Hello.
I am using aria2 for the first time, it is possible that I did something wrong, but it looks to me that aria2 contains some memory leak.

I did a test with arai2 under Linux, when I tried to download ~3M small files through ftp over local network. I started aria2 in rpc mode and call aria2.addUri() . From time to time I called aria2.purgeDownloadResult(). Memory consumption was slowly growing up to 4GB, when aria2 was killed by Linux. When purgeDownloadResult() was called, then RequestGroupMan::downloadResults_.size() == 0, but used memory didn't decrease.

title: TLS1.2 Failure - Handshake not supported
body:
When downloading a file via HTTPS, I get the error

```
05/24 13:28:41 [ERROR] CUID#6 - Download aborted. URI=https://ftp.f3l.de/aurbs/x86_64/aurbs.db
Exception: [AbstractCommand.cc:350] errorCode=1 URI=https://ftp.f3l.de/aurbs/x86_64/aurbs.db
  -> [SocketCore.cc:933] errorCode=1 SSL/TLS handshake failure: The signature algorithm is not supported.
```

The Host has a CACert-Certificate that is trusted globally by my PC.
My aria2c is build against libgnutls.so.30.
When connecting directly with gnutls, I get the following error (Shortened to relevant part):

```
[foor@bar:~]$ gnutls-cli ftp.f3l.de
[...]
- Certificate type: X.509
[...]
- Status: The certificate is trusted. 
- Description: (TLS1.2)-(ECDHE-RSA-SECP256R1)-(AES-128-GCM)
[...]
- Ephemeral EC Diffie-Hellman parameters
 - Using curve: SECP256R1
 - Curve size: 256 bits
- Version: TLS1.2
- Key Exchange: ECDHE-RSA
- Server Signature: RSA-SHA1
- Cipher: AES-128-GCM
- MAC: AEAD
- Compression: NULL
- Options: safe renegotiation,
- Handshake was completed
```

So, the handshake failure does not lie within the range of gnutls.

title: Fix incorrect reading of Content-Disposition
body:
Some servers add an extra ";" at the end of the Content-Disposition header, which caused aria2 unable to set the filename correctly.

Technically, when there is the extra character it ends at state 3 (`CD_BEFORE_DISPOSITION_PARM_NAME`) with the filename already read correctly.

Adding that state to the final checklist would fix it. However there may be other situations which may cause problems, but I haven't tested.

please add c# wrapper for libaria2
fix build error without libssh2
body: `sshSession_` is not defined if libssh2 is not used, so put it after `HAVE_LIBSSH2`

title: aria2 1.19.0
body:
3 months have past since last release.  We have several bug fixes, and new features.  It is a good time to release new one.
I have one pending thing, add an option to set expected fingerprint to validate server's fingerprint in sftp transfer.  After that done, probably, in this week, we are probably going to documentation freeze mode.
#367 could be merged in this release if everything requested gets done before documentation freeze period.

title: Control file only saved if changed?
body:
Currently, control files are saved at every N seconds, where N is given by auto-save-interval, or if aria2 exits gracefully. However, seeded torrents are still considered as active donwloads, and therefore these files change every N seconds, no matter if the torrent actually uploaded in those N seconds or not. 

Would it be possible to only write into the control file, if it changed since last time? (This has already been implemented with writing into the session file.) Then, if there is no activity for a long time, the disc could shut down until needed again. However, with version 1.18.10, the disc is accessed (written to) in every N seconds. 

This feature can be partially achieved by setting auto-save-interval=0, but then if a download starts and a powerloss occurs before aria2 has a chance to exit, then the amount downloaded is lost, because it was not tracked on the disc during download.

title: MacOS X build failure
body:
I try to build aria2 and libaria2 on Mac according to the instruction provided.

Xcode, python, pip, sphinx are installed.

Cloned repository, created build-release folder, symlinked `ln -s ../makerelease-osx.mk Makefil`
Ran `make` and got libcares, libcppunit, libexpat, libgmp, libsqlite3, libz downloaded and successfully built

When it comes to build aria2 it gives an error:

```
mkdir -p aria2.x86_64
( cd aria2.x86_64 && ../../configure \
        --prefix=/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/aria2-1.18.10-24-g4654f19 \
        --bindir=/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/aria2.x86_64 \
        --sysconfdir=/etc \
        --with-cppunit-prefix=/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/x86_64 \
        --enable-static --disable-shared --enable-metalink --enable-bittorrent --disable-nls --with-appletls --with-libgmp --with-sqlite3 --with-libz --with-libexpat --with-libcares --without-libuv --without-gnutls --without-openssl --without-libnettle --without-libgcrypt --without-libxml2 ARIA2_STATIC=yes \
        CFLAGS="-mmacosx-version-min=10.7 -Os -flto -ffunction-sections -fdata-sections -arch x86_64 -I/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/x86_64/include" \
        CXXFLAGS="-mmacosx-version-min=10.7 -Os -flto -ffunction-sections -fdata-sections -arch x86_64 -I/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/x86_64/include" \
        LDFLAGS="-Wl,-dead_strip -mmacosx-version-min=10.7 -Os -flto -ffunction-sections -fdata-sections -L/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/x86_64/lib" \
        PKG_CONFIG_PATH=/Users/alex/Workspace/aria2/release-build/x86_64/lib/pkgconfig \
        )
bash: ../../configure: No such file or directory
make: *** [aria2.x86_64.build] Error 127
```

Then I try to run `autoreconf -i` in sources directory and get this message:

```
 autoreconf -i                                                                                                                             ~/Workspace/aria2(master✗)@Pangaea.local
Can't exec "autopoint": No such file or directory at /usr/local/Cellar/autoconf/2.69/share/autoconf/Autom4te/FileUtils.pm line 345.
autoreconf: failed to run autopoint: No such file or directory
autoreconf: autopoint is needed because this package uses Gettext
```

```
> autoreconf -fiv                                                                                                                           ~/Workspace/aria2(master✗)@Pangaea.local
autoreconf: Entering directory `.'
autoreconf: running: autopoint --force
Can't exec "autopoint": No such file or directory at /usr/local/Cellar/autoconf/2.69/share/autoconf/Autom4te/FileUtils.pm line 345.
autoreconf: failed to run autopoint: No such file or directory
autoreconf: autopoint is needed because this package uses Gettext
```

Here I got stuck...

gettext and autoconf are installed:

```
> brew install gettext autoconf                                                                                                             ~/Workspace/aria2(master✗)@Pangaea.local
Warning: gettext-0.19.4 already installed
Warning: autoconf-2.69 already installed
```

How to fix this error and get aria2 built from sources on Mac?

Thanks.

Update 1:
I gave up building from the repository and tried to build from the latest sourceforge tarball that has configure script ready. Got this error on build:

```
In file included from ../../../src/a2gmp.cc:35:
In file included from ../../../src/a2gmp.h:38:
In file included from /Users/alex/Workspace/aria2_tarball/build-dist/x86_64/include/gmp.h:51:
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin/../include/c++/v1/cstddef:46:9: error: no member named 'ptrdiff_t' in the global namespace
using ::ptrdiff_t;
      ~~^
1 error generated.
make[4]: *** [a2gmp.lo] Error 1
make[4]: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....
make[3]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[2]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: *** [all] Error 2
make: *** [aria2.x86_64.build] Error 2
```

Update 2:
This could be related - https://github.com/openscad/openscad/issues/1314

Update 3:
The 2nd update worked. Adding `#include <stddef.h>` in `gmp.h` or everywhere before including it helped to build.

title: About the algorithm for adaptive used in  `--uri-selector' argument.
body:
Dear Tatsuhiro,

I try to figure out the mechanism of `--uri-selector=adaptive', based on the description in the manual.  And I find the fllowing things on it:

```
   --uri-selector=<SELECTOR>
         [snip]
          If  adaptive  is given,  selects  one  of  the  best  mirrors  
          for  the first and reserved connections.  For supplementary ones,
          it  returns  mirrors  which  has  not  been  tested yet, and if
          each of them has already been tested, returns mirrors  which  has
          to  be  tested again.  Otherwise, it doesn't select anymore mirrors.
          Like feedback, it uses a performance profile of servers.
```

I've read serveral times on the above descrption, but still not-so-clearly understand it.

And then, I try to use the following options to do the testing on this argument:

```
    --server-stat-timeout=6000 \
    --server-stat-of=aaaa \
    --server-stat-if=aaaa  \
    --uri-selector=adaptive
```

Could you please give me some more hints on the  algorithm/mechanism for the  `--uri-selector=adaptive', say, for my above example?

Regards
H.Zhao

title: How can control the maximum number of concurrent connnections to a server from different instances of aria2.
body:
Hi Tatsuhiro,

See the following example:

   for i in `seq 1 100`; do
     aria2c -x1 -j1 http://ftp.cn.debian.org/debian/dists/jessie/main/installer-amd64/current/images/hd-media/boot.img.gz -l ${i}_log --log-level=warn &
  done

In the above case, the `-x1 -j1' only apply to the instance of aria2 from which it issued. 

As a result, I'll simultaneously run 100 concurrent connnections to the same server.  So, how can I control the maximum number of concurrent connnections to a server from different instances of aria2?

Regards

title: About the separator for multiple URIs of a single entity in the input-file.
body:
Dear Tatsuhiro,

You said in the manual that:

```
   -i, --input-file=<FILE>
          Downloads  the  URIs  listed  in  FILE. You can specify multiple
          sources for a single entity by putting multiple URIs on a single
          line  separated by the TAB character.
```

Why it must use the TAB as the separator for multiple URIs of a single entity in the input-file?  I mean, why not let either SPACE or TAB as the separator to facilitate the preparation for the input-file? 

Regards

title: About the support for rsync protocol of aria2.
body:
Dear Tatsuhiro, 

It's well known that the rsync is widely used for settgin the mirror sites.

But, the rsync itself is a sequential tool.  So, would you please or plan to 
add the support for rsync protocol in the further?

Regards

title: When using like this: `-Vtrue --checksum=md5=96528defee417b3cf0d400eeb26d7df8', does the -Vtrue need or not for this case?
body:
Dear Tatsuhiro,

Firstly, thanks a lot for your powerful tool aria2c though I only know it sereral day ago.

Now, I have the following question when using the arguments of  `-Vtrue' and`--checksum' at the same time for http/https/ftp uris.

See the following example used by me for now to obtain some Debian's packages:

aria2c -c -x1 -s40 -k1M -j40 \
--async-dns-server=8.8.8.8,8.8.4.4 \
--lowest-speed-limit=512K --dir=aaa/bbb \
-Vtrue --checksum=md5=96528defee417b3cf0d400eeb26d7df8 \
--auto-save-interval=10 --file-allocation=falloc  \
`paste -sd' ' mDMCTodayHttp.list`

In the above example, the content of file mDMCTodayHttp.list are a lot of uri of Debian's packages using the http/https/ftp protocols.

My question is as follows:

According to the manual of aria2c, I can find the following descriptions:

```
   --realtime-chunk-checksum[=true|false]
          Validate chunk of data by calculating checksum while downloading
          a file if chunk checksums are provided.  Default: true
```

So, considering that for my above example, I also used the  --checksum argument as follows:

--checksum=md5=96528defee417b3cf0d400eeb26d7df8

Does this mean the file's checksum checking will be doing while  downloading?

If so, the should I use the `-Vtrue' argument or not for my case?  I mean, if the`-Vtrue' is a redunant argument for my above usages and should be omitted from the arguments list of aria2c for my case?

Regards.
H.Zhao

title: SSL_pending related issue
body:
We should check that aria2 is not suffered from SSL_pending related issue:

http://www.squid-cache.org/mail-archive/squid-dev/200110/0118.html

We don't use `SSL_pending` in the current code base.
If we try to read everything until SSL_read returns error, then we are OK, but aria2 has rate limit option, so we stop reading somewhere and leave data in SSL object.

GNUTLS has also similar function:
`Function: size_t gnutls_record_check_pending (gnutls_session_t session)`

I don't know about wintls and apple tls regarding this issue.

Technically this is not a bug, I'm writing a tool that parses this file to get info about valid command line options and removing that space will make life a little bit easier :)

title: RPC notification not issued if torrent is already complete
body:
Conditions:
- aria2 is running as a daemon with RPC enabled
- client is communicating with aria2 via JSON-RPC via websocket
- client issues aria2.addTorrent request (not tested: aria2.addUri)
  - options in request:
    - `rpc-save-upload-metadata: true`
    - `seed-ratio: 0`
    - `check-integrity: true`
- torrent is already fully downloaded on client (i.e. it's able to seed)

Expected behavior:
- aria2 fires aria2.onBtDownloadComplete notification (and, if conditions permit, aria2 fires aria2.onDownloadComplete notification)
- no upload metadata file is written to disk

Actual behavior
- aria2 sends no notifications
- upload metadata file (sha1.torrent) is written to disk

title: Update DOCKER.mingw to bump sqlite to 3.8.8.3
WinTLS encryption failure in version >=1.18.8
body:
Since version 1.18.8, aria2c has been complaining about WinTLS being unable to "encrypt a message" and that the "local security authority" could not be contacted. I have double checked previous versions against the latest (1.18.10) and there definitely appears to be an issue in aria2c itself and not my OS/browser settings or anything like that. I tried the different aria2c versions on both my standard OS installation and a clean VM installation with the same OS (Windows XP SP3) and the results are the same.

However, it seems the issue is mostly with larger sites like Google, Dropbox and probably any other sites that uses "proper" encryption and are "up to date" so to speak.

Here is an example session:

![aria2c](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3769056/6616808/70969818-c8b2-11e4-8054-df03c908ba7d.png)

The full commandline from the image:

```
aria2c.exe --no-conf=false --conf-path=.\aria2.conf --input-file=C:\DOCUME~1\Nisto\LOCALS~1\Temp\flashgot.xdrodj9c.default\flashgot.fgt --dir=E:\tls-test --out=sh1psf.rar --referer=https://www.dropbox.com/home/Public/misc --load-cookies=C:\DOCUME~1\Nisto\LOCALS~1\Temp\flashgot.xdrodj9c.default\cookies-9 "--user-agent=Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:36.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/36.0"
```

And my configuration file looks like this:

```
referer=*

force-sequential=false
min-split-size=5M
split=5
max-connection-per-server=16
stream-piece-selector=inorder

check-certificate=false
remote-time=true

no-file-allocation-limit=100M
allow-overwrite=false
auto-file-renaming=true

max-resume-failure-tries=1
always-resume=false

summary-interval=0
download-result=full
```

title: RPC responses seem to be rate-throttled at about 50KB/s
body:
When I have quite a few downloads active in `aria2`, there is a small delay in returning responses to RPC requests.

Right now, I have 100 individual downloads active (with only 2-5% CPU usage on a 933MHz Pentium 3! :D) so `aria2.tellActive` returns quite a bit of output, which takes a couple of seconds to retrieve - even over localhost:

```
Time     Retr  Speed
00:01.0: 128KB (119KB/s)
00:02.0: 256KB (118KB/s)
00:02.3: 272KB (120KB/s)
00:02.6: 350KB (154KB/s)
```

I'm grateful to be able to say that the modem part of my modem-router has never given me any grief, but I guess the router part could be upgraded; requesting RPC data over the LAN from another PC is slower still (because that PC's link is flooded with HTTP requests from `aria2`, presumably).

```
Time     Retr  Speed
00:01.0:  23KB (22KB/s)
00:02.0:  81KB (39KB/s)
00:02.5:  85KB (38KB/s)
00:03.0: 158KB (50KB/s)
00:04.0: 247KB (58KB/s)
```

I would like the RPC data to be returned as fast as aria2 can internally gather the data and serialize it to JSON or XML output. As such, the purpose of this ticket is primarily so I can learn why this slowdown is occuring: is this a bug, or does the RPC server deliberately implement throttling?

title: Revise getRandom facilities
body:
Use one of the following to provide random bytes:
- Windows CryptGenRandom
- Linux getrandom (syscall interface to urandom, without nasty corner
  cases such as file descriptor exhaustion or re-linked /dev/urandom)
- std::device_random (C++ random device, which usually will be urandom)

This also equalizes util::getRandom and SimpleRandomizer (the former
will now use the latter) instead of having essentially two different
PRNG interfaces with potentially different quality.

title: Fix SSLv3 warnings being issued on connection reuse.
body:
And also improve tlsHandshake code a bit in the process, mostly by being
more explicit about error conditions.

title: Clarify encyption options
body: `--bt-require-crypto` and `--bt-min-crypto-level=arc4` seem, from the name, to do pretty much the same thing but from the code it seems they do different things. Could describe if one implies or requires to later.

title: Memory using high on 1.17.0 and later version
body:
Hi,
I am using cross compile to make Aria2 working on arm based NAS. toolchain cs08q1 on optware
the compasion baseline is 1.16.5. setup 8MB disk-cache. concurrent 10 bt download/seeding jobs. after 24hours, the total memory using ~28MB.

same setting update to 1.17.0, some jobs, from start, the memory using increase slowly, after 24hours, the total memory using ~180MB. similar case for the latest 1.18.8.

above results are obtained in my one NAS. it is a QNAP TS 212p with 512MB, I am looking at the memory using for more than one day.
on my another NAS which only has 128MB RAM, the linux sysytem was able to crashed with same bt jobs within 24hours.

this issue was surely introduced from 1.17.0. I try to remove ipv4connectionbackup. seems no any help. Please pay more attention on this issue. It blocks high version aria2 used on NAS/smart Router with small physical memroy.

Thanks,
Mid.

title: Warn about insecure SSL connections.
body: Fixed GH-313

title: Disable SSL3 (by default)
body:
Firefox already disabled SSL3 completely, Chrome will disable it in v30.
In light of broken ciphers and most recently, the poodle attack affecting all block ciphers in SSLv3, the already long broken stream ciphers, etc. aria2 should follow suit and disable SSLv3 entirely in all TLS backends.

It should be feasible to add a pref to enable SSLv3 for those who still need it for backwards compatibility, however, the implementation should then warn that SSLv3 is in use.
- [ ] OpenSSL
- [ ] GnuTLS
- [ ] AppleTLS
- [ ] WinTLS

Use aria2 to mirror websites files. Example:

``` bash
aria2c --mirror www.example.com
```

title: Crash on incorrect RPC multicall request
body:
Aria2 crashes when I call the RPC with an incorrectly formatted JSON data.

This request crashes Aria2:

``` json
[
  [
    {
      "id": "transdroid",
      "jsonrpc": "2.0",
      "method": "aria2.tellActive",
      "params": [
        "token:1234",
        "gid",
        "status",
        "totalLength",
        "completedLength",
        "uploadLength",
        "downloadSpeed",
        "uploadSpeed",
        "numSeeders",
        "dir",
        "connections",
        "errorCode",
        "bittorrent"
      ]
    },
    {
      "id": "transdroid",
      "jsonrpc": "2.0",
      "method": "aria2.tellWaiting",
      "params": [
        "token:1234",
        "gid",
        "status",
        "totalLength",
        "completedLength",
        "uploadLength",
        "downloadSpeed",
        "uploadSpeed",
        "numSeeders",
        "dir",
        "connections",
        "errorCode",
        "bittorrent"
      ]
    }
  ]
]
```

I understand that I supplied the wrong data in the failing case (I got it to work correctly!), but I think Aria2 should handle this more gracefully, like other malformed RPC calls.

BTW Many thanks for making this RPC interface possible -- I have lots of users asking for Aria2 support in Transdroid (see erickok/transdroid#164) and this makes it so reliable and clean to implement!

title: Documentation on rpc secret token incorrect
body:
Following https://github.com/tatsuhiro-t/aria2/blob/master/doc/manual-src/en/aria2c.rst#rpc-authorization-secret-token (and therefor the command line documentation), if --rpc-secret is supplied the secret token should be supplied in every RPC request encoded as "token::$$secret$$" as first parameter.

However, this seems incorrect as the Aria2 does not access this format (instead returning an 'Unauthorized' error), rather it accepts the "token:$$secret$$" format (with only one colon).

Incorrect:

```
curl  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'Accept:application/json' --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"aria2.tellActive","params":["token::1234"],"id":1}' http://localhost:6800/jsonrpc
```

``` json
{"id":1,"jsonrpc":"2.0","error":{"code":1,"message":"Unauthorized"}}
```

Correct:

```
curl  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' -H 'Accept:application/json' --data '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"aria2.tellActive","params":["token:1234"],"id":1}' http://localhost:6800/jsonrpc
```

``` json
{"id":1,"jsonrpc":"2.0","result":[]}
```

Note that at one place in the text the "token:" prefix is correctly used, but in other parts (like the example), it is not.

title: Only strict clean links in .metalink <url> supported. No protocol link start detection
body:
Tried to download files adding some link in .metalink format that starts with tab or line like
"< url type="http" preference="100" >
        http://cs536617v4.vk.me/u41626637/audios/c6e5c4210fad.mp3?extra=ANf6BvC8P86GJU7Lq8k1OHxM-D5nlx-BZROTUjsbYaQikEyXCqU0r207YKNdSfA-VsJ3EIUT2OMGDL5842p9Qp2Sj_54Pfjfkw< /url >"
Found trouble that aria2 detects the very first symbol as the link start
so in log:
"2014-10-15 16:15:39.110892 [DEBUG] [FeedbackURISelector.cc:84] FeedbackURISelector selected %0A%09%09%09http://cs1-29v4.vk.me/p1/b9dccf98490f27.mp3?extra=WzAwRusZC0wz48yyOGjnjuzZxkRZ9DO_NMUxEwoxQyNhem0sX_ctda1IfsZIF6Dmf1GkGeWLIdX7CPdijbd3tD0TsCfucmwLZg%0A%09%09"
and as result:
"2014-10-15 16:15:39.110892 [DEBUG] [FileEntry.cc:435] Found 0 reusable URIs
2014-10-15 16:15:39.110892 [DEBUG] [AbstractCommand.cc:357] Exception caught
Exception: [CreateRequestCommand.cc:100] errorCode=-1 No URI available."

I suggest to add ignore filter of unused symbols (like %0A - %09) in Urls.

title: torrent download never finishes and blockes others tasks in the queue
body:
Hi,

I am using latest version of aria2. I am facing similar issue mentioned on "http://sourceforge.net/p/aria2/discussion/540047/thread/d2000003/"   "Aria2 v1.3.1 won't finish torrent d'load "
Looks like its already fixed few years back but I am still facing it.

I have set queue size to 1 so only one task downloads at a time. When I add a torrent downloading torrent task never marked as completed so others never start and whole queue is blocked dueto this.
I have tried single file torrent and multifile torrent also but got same issue.

Can you please help?

title: Work around libintl's vprintf macro messing with OutputFile::vprintf
body: This solved the errors mentioned in #286.

title: Build error IOFile::vprintf marked override, but does not override
body:
I get this error when building:
`In file included from BufferedFile.h:38:0,
                 from BufferedFile.cc:35:
IOFile.h:80:7: error: 'int aria2::IOFile::vprintf(const char*, va_list)' marked override, but does not override
   int vprintf(const char* format, va_list va) CXX11_OVERRIDE;`

I'm building release 1.18.8 with mingw64-x86_64-gcc 4.9.1. I can't see why the function does not override `OutputFile::vprintf`.

title: abnormal DNS resolution time
body:
Hello,

Since 1.17.1 on windows 7 , DNS resolves are too slow... whatever the DNS server used...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j6LkHEPOKhY

The DNS async library has changed betwen 1.17.0 and 1.17.1, i suspect that...
tatsuhiro has the deep log about it, i wait his 1.18.8 specific version with old DNS library to confirm that ;)

ipconfig /flushdns
pause
70aria2c.exe -v
pause
71aria2c.exe -v
pause
88aria2c.exe -v
pause
del image_._
70aria2c.exe http://test-debit.free.fr/image.iso --stop 13
del image_._
71aria2c.exe http://test-debit.free.fr/image.iso --stop 13
del image_._
88aria2c.exe http://test-debit.free.fr/image.iso --stop 13
pause

body:
I think it will be useful to have a cookies argument in order to load cookies from a string
in addition to loading them from a file.

title: Adler32 checksum
body:
Hello,

   I would like to know if it is possible to add the adler32 checksum in aria2c, which at the moment is not supported (right?).

It will be very useful for us, here at CERN, where we are starting to test aria2c to data transfer.

Thank you,

Vincenzo

title: aria 1.18.7 wintls issue
body:
# Summary

aria2 1.18.7 serving only 1 --rpc-secure=true connection on both win32 and win64 under up to date windows 8.1 and then hangs and consuming 100% CPU from 1 core.
# Flag used

aria2c -l=log -d=here --enable-rpc=true --rpc-secret=MyVERYlongSecretKey --rpc-secure=true --rpc-certificate="C:\path\to\server.pfx" --rpc-private-key="C:\path\to\server.key" --rpc-listen-all
# Version used

aria2c 1.8.17 for windows freshly downloaded from sourceforge.
sha256(aria2c.exe(64)) = 4d4e7ece206ab58029022d8db140c53b4e311e3bd96139a86c748a392a8e8207
sha256(aria2c.exe(32)) = ff68931f360dbe32ac29c73bb4154cf6a7a5628ea8e586cbf5f259c6f0ccc480

aria2c -v output: 

> aria2 version 1.18.7
> Copyright (C) 2006, 2014 Tatsuhiro Tsujikawa
>

> System: Windows 6.2

> Visit http://aria2.sourceforge.net/
# Details
- when executed with these flags aria2 will start normally serving 1 rpc request and then hangs with 1 cpu core seems to busywait (100%)
- I can reproduce the bug at will ~~and I could not find a work around~~ (please see workaround section).
- the certificates are self generated.
- the JSON RPC client used is aria2-webui.
- this problem is not presented with the non-encrypted aria2 json rpc server

Not really a workaround but aria 1.18.5 is not effected

title: Torrent completes, then immediately reads 0B
body:
This is a small magnet link download I have tried on 3 different systems with the same results. I have tried deleting the 0B file that is created, removing the save file, specifying different download directory, same results. Here is the output of my aria2c command. I can provide more info if needed. I assume this is a n00b mistake that I'm missing. I also noticed that it seems to be downloading the magnet link, then turning it into a torrent, and downloading it again, but 0B this time.

title: Segmentation fault using HTTPS on OS X 10.7
body:
I'm getting crashes when I try to download from some URLs with an https prefix on 10.7.

$ aria2c https://www.google.com
Segmentation fault: 11

The same URLs download as expected with HTTP:

$ aria2c http://www.google.com
[#a98f7e 0B/0B CN:1 DL:0B] 

09/03 17:33:57 [NOTICE] Download complete: $path_to_file

Download Results:
gid   |stat|avg speed  |path/URI
======+====+===========+=======================================================
a98f7e|OK  |   4.1KiB/s| $path_to_file

Status Legend:
(OK):download completed.

I used google.com as an example; note that the URLs in question are valid signed URLs that download successfully in a web browser. The problem does not seem to apply to all https URLs, for example the following may be downloaded without issue:

https://download.thinkbroadband.com/5MB.zip

title: Loop range missing.
body: When the FTP address contains "[" ,we will get a feedback error message" Loop range is missing".

title: Enable dynamicbase and nxcompat in Windows binaries
body: Should be safe to pull, even at this stage short before a release. I build and run my own binaries (aria2c and diverese mm tools such as ffmpeg and mkvtoolnix) with these flags since years.

title: aria2 1.18.8
body:
The expected release date is 9/6.
The documentations are now frozen due to translation.

title: Max overall download limit with rpc
body:
If I include the `max-download-limit` option in a json-rpc call to `aria2.addUri` then the download speed is limited as expected. If instead I use the `max-overall-download-limit` option the download runs at full speed. Should the `max-overall- download-limit` be honored by `addUri`?

I'm using 1.18.1 on Ubuntu 14.04.

echo http://www.example.com|aria2c -i-

title: Fixed segfault for unsupported encodings
body: After failing a null check filter is being used anyway causing a segmentation fault. This seems to fix the issue.

title: aria2 1.18.7
body:
We have a regression which burns CPU 100% in torrent download with -V option and build failure on Big Endian machines.
Release 1.18.7 fixes these problems.
It will be released in a couple of days.

title: Try to set sane limits for RLIMIT_NO_FILE
body:
E.g. on OSX the default is 256, which isn't exactly compatible with
torrent downloads.

It's really annoying to either have to setup a wrapper script or remember to call `ulimit` on the shell. :p
The documentation could be better, and probably the option name too. :(
@tatsuhiro-t Any suggestions?

title: Decrease PBKDF2 iterations
body:
Now PBKDF2 clearly pauses aria2 when issuing RPC call.
It took just 30ms for busy loop.
I'd like to make it less, possibly 3ms or less.

title: Android: can't download big files
body:
Aria downloads entire file, but on complete it cuts file to ~600mb.
File size: 4 977 730 608 bytes.

Aria says:

```
[#f42fd9 4.6GiB/4.6GiB(99%) CN:1 DL:3.8MiB ETA:1s]
07/03 18:19:44 [NOTICE] Download complete:
```

Downloaded by aria file size: 682 763 312  bytes.

I use HTTP URL to download file. My storage has NTFS file system.
My config file:

```
# configuration file for aria2c
disable-ipv6=true
rpc-listen-all=true
enable-rpc=true
file-allocation=none
```

I tried with file-allocation=none and file-allocation=trunc with the same result.
With small files all works properly.

Depending on my calculations it cuts 4gb from the end of file (4 977 730 608 - 4 294 967 296 = 682 763 312).

title: aria2 1.18.6
body:
Thanks to @nmaier , Windows build will use its native TLS backend instead of OpenSSL from this release.  This will free us from releasing binary every time OpenSSL security bug is found.
The schedule is: documentation freeze happens 5 Jul, release date is 13 Jul.

title: Fix MessageDigests
body:
This adds a complete internal implementation, that also works on big endian correctly.
As it happens my PBKDF2 implementation wasn't really supporting big-endian. This wouldn't be so much of a problem in aria2c's case as the derived keys never left the process. Only `make check` on big-endian was effectively affected.
Performance-wise the hash implementations should be fast enough. Actually as fast as or even a little faster than the shipped and `brew`ed `openssl dgst` implementations on my MacBook Air when hashing some medium to large files, but I'm not sure how much can be attributed to the OpenSSL file I/O abstraction layers...

Also remove WinMessageDigest, because it is incomplete at least lacking SHA-224 (or more on XP < SP3).

I first implemented this stuff here (out of curiosity mainly):
https://github.com/nmaier/crypto
There are some unit tests (against RFC test vectors and/or Python aka. OpenSSL)

title: Improve compiler/platform/libs information in logs

diagnose/reproduce user-reported problems.

Also make INFO logs include usedLibs() output.

title: Remove spurious CXX11_OVERRIDE to make cov-build happy.
body:
@tatsuhiro-t In #232 you mention that cov-build does not produce the necessary coverage required for uploading builds.

When I just tried cov-build, I was able to reproduce. The reason seems to be https://github.com/tatsuhiro-t/aria2/blob/master/src/ValueBase.h#L325 : `virtual void visit(const T& t) CXX11_OVERRIDE`. AFAIK you cannot really use override with templates like this. Since `ValueBase.h` is included in most units one way or the other, this led to abysmal coverage results. 
Removing that `CXX11_OVERRIDE` gave me:
-  Compiling with a `g++-4.7` on Debian x86_64 against GnuTLS after some `cov-configure --compiler g++-4.7 -p gcc` then using `cov-build --dir cov-int make V=1`:

``` sh
379 C/C++ compilation units (100%) are ready for analysis
The cov-build utility completed successfully.
```
- Compiling with a `g++4.8` (brew) on OSX 10.9 x86_64 against AppleTLS after some `cov-configure --compiler g++-4.8 -p gcc` then using `cov-build --dir cov-int make V=1`:

``` sh
380 C/C++ compilation units (99%) are ready for analysis
The cov-build utility completed successfully.
```

The missing units being `AppleTLS*.cc`, because cov-build cannot find the (Framework) `<Security/Security.h>` header for whatever reason.

As a non-admin for the aria2 project, I cannot post builds.
(Also, I cannot currently see Defects for aria2 in Coverity ATM, but they seem to have had problems with their infrastructure all day long, so right now I'm waiting to see if this clears up by itself or if I have to contact their support).

title: aria2 can't create Settings folder in Win 8.1
body:
Current release aria2 at 1st run tends to create default folder with settings in c:\users\user\.aria2. When started as a service via NSSM, in Win7 aria2 can create it only when run with User credentials, but not with service default Local System credentials. In Win8.1 it can't create .aria2 folder regardless of service or Cmd run credentials, probably since the app is portable. As a result, aria2 can start as a service only in Paused mode, and can't be Resumed. It gives the error in NSSM log:

"Specify at least one URL.
Usage: aria2c [OPTIONS] [URI | MAGNET | TORRENT_FILE | METALINK_FILE]...
See 'aria2c -h'"

I had to manually copy .aria2 folder from Win7 to Win8.1 c:\users\user\ , then added service startup string in NSSM GUI when creating aria2 service:
--conf-path=c:\users\user\.aria2\aria2.conf

After that aria2 service started normally with Local System credentials, and could write logs to .aria2 folder. I didn't try, but the same issue is likely to occur when running aria2 from Cmd. Is it possible to fix that bug?

title: Add an option to configure to disable the use of docutils

title: Resilient tokens
body:
Alright, the secret token RPC stuff has two issues:
1. Timing attacks: An attacker may figure out the secret by measuring the time it takes to do a request. Usual string comparisons will exit on the first mismatch (or even on mismatched length before that), so it is feasible to time this. The "better" the password candidate the more chars will be compared, the more time a request takes.This PR addresses this in the first two commits by doing a HMAC on the token (fixed length result) and the using a hopefully (mostly) constant-time array compare.
2. Brute-force (dict) attacks: An attacker may simply try to brute-force his way in. aria2 is damn fast processing those requests, which makes it to try out hundreds if not thousands of passwords per second. The usual way t limit this is to use a real KDF, such as PBKDF2, bcrypt or scrypt. The former seems to be good enough for our case, as we do not need any additional protection (e.g. memory-constraints scrypt introduces) since the secret is not that secret on the local system anyway in that an attacker with local access can just read it from the config/commandline/process memory dump anyway and a remote attacker will not see our derived key at any point. Hence the other two commits implement PBKDF2 and use that to compare tokens.

title: Enable Win TLS in Mingw32 build
body:
Currently, we build Mingw32 build with OpenSSL.
It works fine, but the biggest downside is user have to setup ca certificates.
I think Win TLS uses cert store provided by Windows OS, so user don't have to setup them and no need to downgrade security using --check-certificate=false.

@nmaier If current WinTLS is ready to go, I'll build aria2 with it and upload to sf.net to gauge interests.

title: Warn about using rpc without auth.
body:
When enabling aria2 RPC, but not specifying any auth (`--rpc-user` or `--rpc-secret`), aria2c should warn that this enables a host of well known attacks, incl. attackers potentially having the ability to control a running instance just by the users opening an unrelated attack website in any browser.

`--rpc-user` has similar problems, but this auth method is already deprecated and will already output a warning per 7d1aa887ee5f00ecdfe8a7d8f71becf81018e55e. However, IMO it would be a good idea to improve that warning to actually mention security implications when continuing to use `--rpc-user`.

title: Parallel connections not working
body:
Parallel connections when downloading files over HTTP/HTTPS doesn't seem to be working for me

```
aria2c -x 20 -s 20 https://storage.googleapis.com/chrome-canary/GoogleChromeCanary.dmg
```

Gives speed around 80KB/s

When I try to download same file using [axel](http://freecode.com/projects/axel)

```
axel -n 20 https://storage.googleapis.com/chrome-canary/GoogleChromeCanary.dmg
```

I get 520KB/s

I'm running aria2 version 1.18.3 on OSX Mavericks installed using homebrew.

title: Lower -k min
body:
Possible Values: 1M -1024M
, said manpage
while I want 128 kilobyte

title: Avoid bash way, improve posix shell portability
body:
Bash accepts
test "$AAA" == "BBB"; then
but some posix compliant shell cannot handle this.
Thay can handle
test "$AAA" = "BBB"; then
only.
Could you use posix way?

title: Disable color in Windows Console
body: In some situations the coloring in the Windows Console can be hard to read, would be nice to have an option to disable all coloring.

title: Multi-OS Packaging Question?
body:
I'm planning on creating a django webapplication with pyinstaller.

What would be the best way to distribute a cross-platform packaged version of aria2 to be utlizied within aria2? 

Thanks for you time. 

chavenor

title: NOT safe using JSON-RPC with HTTP GET
body:
It's not safe with JSON-RPC using HTTP GET, even if use --rpc-passwd.
1. `aria2c --enable-rpc --rpc-user=username --rpc-passwd=password`
2. Login with some webui using HTTP GET like [this](http://ziahamza.github.io/webui-aria2/).  @ziahamza
3. Now everyone can make a RPC using `http://localhost:6800/jsonrpc` without password. (make XSS like [this](http://jsbin.com/ASACuHE/1) )

Browser will keep basic authentication status with remote host using http GET. It would be stolen to download evil `/etc/resove.conf` or `/root/.bash_profile` to user.

title: Make GnuTLS log level dependent on the aria2 ones
body:
Spin-off from #179 

> The thing is usually we don't want gnutls debug log in aria2 debug log output.

Why not? Helps debugging stuff, such as #179?

title: GnuTLS 3.1.18/3.2.4 cannot connect to tn123.org
body:
Well, actually it can, but it cannot when used by aria2 (see #177)
Other SSL libraries (OpenSSL, AppleTLS, WinTLS, and nss in Firefox) can connect just fine.
`gnutls-cli` can connect just fine as well.

3.1.10 and earlier (which translates to 3.2.0 IIRC) cannot connect due to a bug, so that is expected. However, later versions should be able to connect.

body:
Hi,

It may be possible that my problem isn't one but I don't find the solution. I'm trying to download a torrent file from a private tracker with aria2 and I get anytime a timeout exception.
Exception : [AbstractCommand.cc:303] error_code = 2 TimeOut
Anyway, it works perfectly with any public trackers and my torrent is downloaded without any problems with softwares like utorrent, qbittorrent.
Do you have any ideas ?

Regards,

Yohann PETIOT

title: Release 1.18.3
body: I messed up the handling of `--bt-max-open-files` and it makes aria2 RPC service unusable (especially for torrents). We need another maintenance release in this month.

title: --check-integrity doesn't prevent download from happening again
body:
This is with 1.17.1 (as it's the last version I can easily compile on CentOS).

I have a metalink file:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<metalink version="3.0" generator="test" xmlns="http://www.metalinker.org/">
<files>
        <file name="testfile">
                <size>104857600</size>
                <verification>
                        <hash type="md5">681025d06b3fec0117efcd5f1d1d8002</hash>
                </verification>
                <resources>
                        <url type="http" location="us" preference="50">http://speedtest.constant.com/100MBtest.bin</url>
                </resources>
        </file>
</files>
</metalink>
```

and I invoke aria2c:

aria2c --check-integrity=true --allow-overwrite=true --follow-metalink=mem big.metalink

The first time I run it, everything works properly.  The file is downloaded, and checksum verification takes place.  The second time I run it, 'testfile' is deleted, and redownloaded, even though the checksum already matches.

My next thought was to try with --continue, which corrects this problem, but introduces another problem.  If I replace 'testfile' with a smaller file, then try:

aria2c --check-integrity=true --allow-overwrite=true --follow-metalink=mem --continue big.metalink

I receive an error, and the file is corrupted (md5 doesn't match)

```
[#24c499 100MiB/100MiB(100%) CN:0] [Checksum:#24c499 99MiB/100MiB(99%)]
12/24 12:20:30 [ERROR] Checksum error detected. file=testfile

12/24 12:20:30 [NOTICE] Download GID#24c4994baedd709b not complete: testfile

Download Results:
gid   |stat|avg speed  |path/URI
======+====+===========+=======================================================
24c499|ERR |   9.4MiB/s|testfile
```

So, there seems to be something wrong here.
- check-integrity overwrites the file without continue, even if the hash matches
- allow-overwrite doesn't actually overwrite the file in the event of a hash mismatch.

Ultimately, we're using aria2c to download a few files via metalink.  We periodically attempt to redownload the files to update them.  The files are not necessarily different each time we run aria2c, and we'd prefer to not redownload them if the hash is the same.  In the event of a hash mismatch, we'd expect aria2c to delete the existing file and redownload (which is not currently being done).

title: Release 1.18.2
body:
I plan to release next version 1.18.2. This will fix broken --on-\* options in *nix platforms. Also it may feature binary Mac OS X binary release (might not be available soon).

The release date will be Dec 25 or 26, documentation freezes one week earlier (18 or 19) due to translation.

title: A session should save all available files per torrent
body:
When a multifile torrent is added for download, a user can select just a few files out of many to download initially. Once the session is saved, it should preserve the list of available and completed files for each downloaded torrent.

When the session is later reopen, a user should be able to select available for download files from the same torrent, non-selected during 1st download.

---

Pls cancel, as a user can open original torrent file instead if available.


title: Fix static builds on darwin
body: While investigating on how to provide easy-to-use static builds on darwin, I found out that ARIA2_STATIC=yes is broken on OSX...

title: Stuff some memory holes
body:
There are quite a bunch of memory holes due to padding of members to certain alignment bounds. This in particular affects 64-bit, where you need 8-byte alignments of pointers, but 32-bit is also affected where it is mostly 4-byte alignments.

I reordered the members of the worst offenders (via `-Wpadded`) so that padding can be avoided (mostly). The commit message includes some stats.

Bonus: dead store in Piece, as indicated by the clang static analyzer.

title: Implement and provide OSX staticly linked binaries
body:
Spin-off of #156.

Most mac users won't have a development environment or the skills to compile aria2 themselves. While aria2 is provided by most *nix package managers, and there are official Windows and Android build, there is no good way to obtain binaries for OSX.

Unfortunately, it is quite hard to get an OSX toolchain working on a non-OSX platform.
- [x] Create first static builds
- [x] Universal binaries
- [x] Installable pkg in a dmg

title: High CPU usage with 1.18.0 and above
body: Add any magnet link to aria2 after file allocation complete it use a huge amount of cpu compare to 1.17.1 top show 97-100 %CPU ![screen shot 2013-12-03 at 8 59 04 pm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2471128/1664258/5bfd8f66-5c24-11e3-8e23-2925915e3683.png) https://www.dropbox.com/s/d8rdhm15lmdjx85/log.zip

title: OSX + Homebrew compilation caveat
body:
autoreconf had a problem where it couldn't find autopoint even though gettext was installed. I think that hombrew, a package manager on OSX, doesn't symlink autopoint into /usr/local/bin by default. Can someone confirm this? To solve, i had to run `brew link --force gettext`

(using OSX 10.9)

title: -S option doesn't print torrent url contents
body: -S option doesn't print torrent url contents

title: Colors
body: Review comments from https://github.com/tatsuhiro-t/aria2/pull/151 addressed and rebased.

title: Colors
body:
- Implement minimal color support for WinConsoleFile
- Make sure things are wired up correctly
- Add some colors to progress reports.

Any issues I missed?

title: Reducing the number of open file descriptors
body:
Hi,

When seeding torrents, aria keeps every file of that torrent open. I understand why that is the case, but can we close some of them? One idea would be to close files of a torrent when no peers are requesting data, and reopening them when they do. Would that be viable? I don't know how peers ask for data in BitTorrent protocol, and if they time out on such queries. Would reopening those files introduce enough overhead that peers discard us as a source?

I found myself increasing the limits on the number of opened files when aria hit the  4000 mark.

There may be other places where this kind of bugs sleep.

title: Implement WinTLS
body:
Implement TLS on Windows via native OS support aka. WinTLS.

The implementation uses Schannel, which - unlike most implementations - requires manually reads/write to the socket and passing the data along to the library.

There are quite some pitfalls when it comes to Schannel. I tried my best to comment these pitfalls.
Right now the code is default `--without`, because I didn't have tested it extensively with different servers or even any Windows except Win7.

Please review.

title: Figure out the internal ./intl
body:
Right now, gettext is configured to use an internal `intl`, which is all nice and dandy, if you get a tarball that actually contains the library.
Otherwise, you may need to run `gettextize --intl` yourself, which, to add insult to injury, is actually  deprecated. `autoreconf` will just invoke `autopoint`, which does not necessarily add `./intl`.
This makes it unnecessarily hard for new folk to modify and/or contribute.

Possible solutions:
- Just commit `./intl`
- Remove support for internal gettext by using `AM_GNU_GETTEXT([external])`  and remove remaining `./intl`stuff from configure.ac and Makefile.am.
- Leave as is, but document `gettextize --intl`.

title: Fix Windows CTRL-C behavior (SIGINT + SIGTERM)
body:
signal handling on windows is very unreliable, and may not accept multiple CTRL-C hits, or no CTRL-C hits at all in some environments (native executable under cygwin).

By switching to the Windows-own `SetConsoleCtrlHandler` this is rectified. However, this adds some complexity as well, because the "signals" will now be dispatched to another thread.

I also added a simple Lock implementation, which, as the commit message correctly states, is a no-op on platforms other than Windows. This isn't a problem, though, as the only code using it now is only potentially multi-threaded on Windows.

title: Audit all uses of std::move()
body:
When `std::move` may cause bad code when used in a statement (argument list) that references the moved pointer a couple of times, depending on the optimizing compiler, because the order of evaluation is undefined per the language standard.

With the great `std::unique_ptr` rewrite, a lot of code now uses `std::move`, which already caused a couple of bugs, such as

``` c++
auto res = rpc::getMethod(req.methodName)
  ->execute(std::move(req), e_);
```

(`req` might be moved before `getMethod(req.methodName)` is called)
which was fixed by splitting into multiple statments:

``` c++
auto method = rpc::getMethod(req.methodName);
auto res = method->execute(std::move(req), e_); 
```

Therefore, all uses of `std::move` should be audited.

title: Unbuffered disk writes can cause massive fragmentation
body:
I loaded a couple of thousand smallish (<1MB) files with 6 concurrent downloads to an NTFS partion on Win7 and had plenty of consecutive free space. The downloaded files had a little over 8 fragments per file after the queue completed as analyzed by contig.exe.

The main reason seems to be that aria2 does not buffer writes at all (not even stdlib buffers) and leaves this entirely to the OS. ProcessMonitor saw direct WriteFile calls with usually 1400 length, i.e one per received TCP segment, which is bad for a couple of reasons:
- Many small writes cause many syscalls, which isn't exactly great performance-wise.
- Many small writes may cause excessive fragmentation, as demonstrated here.
- The non-power-of-two size of the writes doesn't play nicely with cluster sizes and file system implementations.

I actually implemented a PoC write buffer in AbstractDiskWriter, which indeed reduces the fragmentation significantly. That PoC still has a couple of problems, such as AbstractDiskWriter being a suboptimal place for buffers and thus not working well when using --split.

There should be some buffering, ideally a per-connection receive buffer (instead of per-file write buffer).

title: Fix a bad std::move in HttpConnection
body:
C++ Standard says that the order of evaluation of arguments is
unspecified. Even if it wasn't, std::move would run first, invalidating
the httpRequest smartptr, so that httpRequest->createRequest() would be
executed on the invalid ptr.
Some compilers might be smart enough to correct this error, clang XCode
Edition surely is not (not should it).

title: SessionSerializer: Truly unique URIs
body:
Before, only spent uris where sanitized not to be contained within
remaining uris. Change this so that each uri in the
union(remaining,spent) get saved once at most.
The order of the uris will won't be changed, with remaining uris going
first followed by spent uris.

Also avoid copying the uri std::strings around during dupe checking,
usually resulting in better performance regarding CPU and space.

title: "Too large size" on Android build
Add configure support for linking tcmalloc_minimal and/or jemalloc
body:
Both tcmalloc_minimal and jemalloc outperform the native malloc
implemention on Windows (MSVCRT) in terms of committed memory
consumption (~-30%) and performance (e.g. far less page faults, ~-60%),
depending, of course, on the actual workload.
The longer the download queue, the bigger the impact ;)

On *nix the picture is a little different... tcmalloc usually still
outperforms the native malloc implementation, but not that significantly
than on Windows. jemalloc however is only marginally better than recent
native Linux implementations, while it is already used by some BSD as the
native allocator.

tcmalloc is part of gperftools and very mature and tested by now. It
doesn't work on OSX in the default configuration, however.
http://code.google.com/p/gperftools/

jemalloc is the default allocator at least on FreeBSD and NetBSD and
used in Firefox.
http://www.canonware.com/jemalloc/index.html

this update pt-br docs with a example of howto create a certificate using utility keychain access for using encripted downloads.
another small correct typo erros in rst chars (~~--~~) on metalink titles

title: Http download error
body: Log file. I used aria2 as launch daemons on OS X seem like conflict with DNSCrypt (change DNS to 127.0.0.54) it only happen when aria2 start with system magnet link download fine but not http "sudo launchctl unload" then load aria2 download file with no problem. 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600629 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1344] Not considered: fe80::1%lo0 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600648 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1344] Not considered: 127.0.0.1 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600664 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1344] Not considered: ::1 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600681 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1342] Found configured address: 127.0.0.53 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600698 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1342] Found configured address: 127.0.0.54 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600715 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1342] Found configured address: 127.0.0.55 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600762 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1344] Not considered: fe80::129a:ddff:feab:2644%en0 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600779 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1342] Found configured address: 192.168.1.2 2013-04-11 04:44:48.600793 [INFO] [SocketCore.cc:1349] IPv4 configured=1, IPv6 configured=0

title: LibUV: Implement LibuvEventPoll
body:
LibUV event will use the best available polling method on a system, kind of
like aria2 does already with the different *EventPoll implementations. 
However, libuv may support different/newer polling mechanisms; for example on
Windows it will use IO Completion Ports which are superior to select() ;)

This stuff isn't ready just yet.

First of all, building libuv with mingw-w64 sucks:
https://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=3610440&group_id=202880&atid=983354
https://github.com/joyent/libuv/pull/774

And then, it might be good, or not, to not prefer libuv over all other
implementations. (Over win select() certainly :p)

Also, I didn't test-drive this enough.
So it's a WIP. Feedback welcome.

title: AppleMD: Add destructors to make compilers happy
body: Simple stuff ;)

title: session file and config file (redundancy)
body:
shouldn't the session file ignore prefs already set in the config file ?
minimizing the size of the file and allowing resuming from differents OSs ? eg: the download location changes in each os while pointing to the same folder

title: Use library-provided hostname verification where available
body:
GnuTLS offers some APIs for verifying host names since some time. Use
that if available.
OpenSSL .next will also offer something similar, so use that with
OpenSSL TLS when available.

I left the old code in for now, in case some folks are still using very
old versions of GnuTLS (uncommon) or non-bleeding-edge versions of
OpenSSL (very common).

title: AppleTLS: Fixup checkDirection() to return WANT_READ by default
body:
As discussed in issue #61.
The log is a lot shorter now :D

title: AppleTLS: Support credentials via file
body:
It should be possible to load a pubkey/privkey combo from a PEM (DER-encoded) and use that to setup SSL connections in AppleTLS.

Implement this.

title: AppleTLS: Support credentials via KeyChain
body:
Right now there is no way to specify which cert to use for the https server.
Add support for specifying the cert fingerprint of a KeyChain cert.

body:

aria2 1.16.5, Mac OSX 10.8.2

<script src="https://gist.github.com/kax4/4d3fde3790b1dc861803.js"></script>

title: AppleTLS: Implement native TLS support on OSX
body:
As mentioned in issue #56, by @antbryan and others, OSX provides platform SSL/TLS support.
I took the opportunity to implement just that in aria2. As AppleTLS uses the KeyChain, it will also automatically use the root CAs stored there, so no more worries about ca-bundle, like the stuff @zhuangya encountered.
Besides that, I also implemented message digests via OSX platform support.

This stuff is still somewhat experimental. It should be default secure, but I'm not an expert :p
Maybe mark it experimental for now and require explicitly configuring with --with-appletls?

Also, the configure stuff still is somewhat crappy. As I didn't implement the RC4/DH stuff, it still needs gcrypt/nettle/gmp/openssl. But openssl is disabled when appletls is enabled, so one less option. Not sure about that...

IIRC this stuff should build and work in OSX 10.4 and later.

Feel free to comment, but please do not merge before I had a chance to test more compiler configs and SSL scenarios

title: Make configure argument meaning more consistent and obvious.
body:
Most other software uses --disable/--without for features it does build
or at least check by default.

Change aria2 configure options so that:
- --enable-*: do not build by default, unless --enable specified
- --disable-*: check and build by default, unless --disable specified
- --with-*: do not use by default, unless --with specified
- --without-*: check and use by default, unless without specified

title: Gzipped sessions (Take 2)
body:
See pr #52 for take 1

read/write should not support 64-bit size_t. write also should return 0 when gzwrite returns -1 at some point

title: Check for sys/signal.h and/or signal.h (Take 2)
body:
mingw-w64 does not actually have sys/signal.h, while OSX currently has a
broken signal.h
Better check the presence of both and use sys/signal.h if present, else
signal.h

title: Check for sys/signal.h and/or signal.h
body:
mingw-w64 does not actually have sys/signal.h, while OSX currently has a
broken signal.h
Better check the presence of both and use sys/signal.h if present, else
signal.h

title: Gzipped sessions
body:
Saved sessions may very large, as in hundreds and even thousands of
megabyte when dealing with large queues.
Add support to save and reload sessions to gzipped files, when libz is
available.

The session serializer will output gzipped contents when the file ends
with .gz, while the input file reader (UriListParser) will accept
whatever is thrown at it.

OK (963)
PASS: aria2c

title: Allow for out-of-tree Sphinx builds
body:
e.g.

``` sh
$ pwd
/home/me/build-aria2
$ ../aria2/configure && make -C doc
```

title: Fix clang errors and warnings
body:
First fix an error that's present either due Apple messing up their headers, or clang messing up the aliasing of a function defined multiple times.

clang has pretty neat diagnostics. So fix the warnings it spits out.
Only some warnings regarding insecure fmt(gettext()) missing (--enable-nls) and using deprecated on OSX daemon() left.

Code now compiles and tests on OSX with:
./configure CC=cc CXX=c++
+bittorrent +metalink +zlib +libxml2

OK (961)
PASS: aria2c

title: Do not reference RequestGroups longer than necessary
body:
There is an initial vector of SharedHandle<RequestGroup> to seed the
DownloadEngine. This vector was however kept alive via main.cc ->
MultiUrlRequestInfo up until the program exits, hence effetively leaking
all initial RequestGroups and associated object instances.

Hence, as a matter of dirty-workaround, drop the contents of that initial
vector as soon as it is not required any longer.

title: Detect console with on Windows
body:
Windows, too, has an API for determining the actual console width.

Don't ask me about the -2. I did the patch a couple of month back and remember this was required for whatever reason (instead of just -1).

title: Fix addDownloadResult infinite loop when max-download-results is reached (take 2)
body:
RequestGroupMan::addDownloadResult will to purge the oldest result according to max-download-results, or at least this is how it is supposed to be.

The implementation however does not actually purge anything, ever. The while loop is therefore an infinite busy loop, halting aria2 while buring CPU circles.

Forgive my somewhat rusty C++/STL

The first take one was actually quite wrong :p

title: Fix addDownload infinite loop when max-download-results is reached
body:
RequestGroupMan::addDownloadResult will to purge the oldest result according to max-download-results, or at least this is how it is supposed to be.

The implementation however does not actually purge anything, ever. The while loop is therefore an infinite busy loop, halting aria2 while buring CPU circles.

Forgive my somewhat rusty C++/STL

title: How to properly seed torrents & maintain a session
body:
Hi,

I've been using aria2 for a few days now, it is a great tool but there's one thing I can't figure out. I want to seed a few torrents simultaneously, but I can't configure it properly.

My config:

```
continue
dir=/home/kuba/Downloads
file-allocation=falloc
log-level=info
max-connection-per-server=4
min-split-size=5M
enable-rpc
enable-dht
bt-save-metadata
rpc-save-upload-metadata
force-save
#seed-ratio=3
check-unverified
bt-seed-unverified
save-session=/home/kuba/.aria2/session
input-file=/home/kuba/.aria2/session
```

What I'm aiming for is to run an instance of aria2 and then add downloads via rpc (I use webui-aria2). What happened to me when I first tried to seed multiple torrents was that torrents disappeared entirely after completion. I then figured out saving sessions, using input files, saving metadata, and recently force-save'ing. That worked fine until I got 4 jobs at the same time (4 metadata + 4 actual seeding jobs). But then I restarted the instance and I can see 4 metadata jobs, but no seeding is done (or maybe they disappear from rpc interface, I can't really tell). When I restart one of the metadata jobs, they disappear too from the webui but they're saved in the session file and they're back up again after restarting (metadata jobs, still no actual seeding).

I have no idea where to go from now, the output is cluttered with errors saying that udp is not supported yet, I don't know if it has any effect on this case.

By the way, if I can't connect to trackers via udp, does it mean I'm not connected to as many peers as I could be?

title: Option enable-mmap doesn't work on OpenWrt
body:
I'm so happy Aria2 finally has a cache-like option: enable-mmap! I built it for OpenWrt, but when I try to run "aria2c --enable-mmap=true" it says unrecognized option `--enable-mmap'. I can't find enable-mmap option using "aria2c -h#all" either, even though I can find option "--force-save" and use it, which was added in the latest version.  However, when I build it on Ubuntu, it works all right, do you have any ideas? 

UPDATE: I've noticed HAVE_MMAP is not set to 1 when do the configure check. In the Configure.log file, it says "Checking working mmap ....no". But I guess mmap should be available on Openwrt, so I modified Configure file and skipped the mmap check, looks all good right now.

title: Feature request:  Don't lost completed jobs between session...
body:

For a few torrents it's not a problem but if you try use aria2 like a torrent manager with a large number of torrent jobs is painfull resume all.

I suggest the inclusion of one option like "--persistent-job", that force aria2 always save the related job in the save session file.  And it can work for all types of jobs for log purpose...

Thank for the attention and all excellent work in aria2.

title: Overall download limit does not work as far as I can tell
body:
First things first, I'm calculating downspeed using

``` ruby
def downspeed
  aria2_client.tell_active.inject(0) do |sum, download|
    sum += Integer(download["downloadSpeed"])
  end
end
```

Sampling this 10 times with 5s pause I get 

``` ruby
[461418, 463992, 468939, 472702, 475559, 470763, 478367, 476623, 471814, 472302].
  instance_eval { reduce(:+) / size.to_f } # => 471247.9
```

This is an average of 460 kilobytes. Currently there is no limit set and 460 kb is roughly my line limit. So things are working as expected. Theoretically, I should be able to halve this speed to roughly 200 kilobytes by issuing:

``` ruby
a.global_opts["max-overall-download-limit"] # => "0"
a.change_global_opt("max-overall-download-limit", "200K") # => "OK"
a.global_opts["max-overall-download-limit"] => "204800"
```

After 1 minute and 5 minutes I get the following samplings:

``` ruby
[787563, 687335, 737474, 616957, 379094, 261147, 762531, 712533, 713150, 528384] 
 # => avg: 618616.8
[241659, 295719, 204817, 291366, 306119, 229627, 515800, 438093, 409138, 354970]
 # => avg: 328730.8
```

This just seems broken to me because both average above the limit I set for aria. Furthermore, I've used out-of-band monitoring tools like the `iftop` command to see what the actual bandwidth consumption is. In both cases, it hovers around 460 kb which is my line speed.

It is worth noting that if I seriously restrict the usage (10K) then aria does actually limit it - but not to 10K! 

``` ruby
[116286, 104248, 107772, 115253, 84493, 42524, 118660, 105615, 110290, 118871].
  instance_eval { reduce(:+) / size.to_f } # => 102401.2 # 100 K!
```

I have a couple of questions:
1. Is my download-speed-measuring function OK? Is there anything I can do to improve it?
2. Am I doing something stupid with the max-overall-download-limit option?

Some points to note:
1. All my downloads are added via metalinks: I call `addUri` with a `http://foo.metalink` file.
2. This is on Ubuntu 12.04 using the PPA. Aria is at 1.13.0.

Aria2 should create the config directory in $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/aria2 instead of ~/.aria2

Please fix this, thank you!

title: Torrent download >100% complete
body:
STR:
- Start downloading a torrent with e.g. --select-file=3,11
- At some point CTRL-C to cleanly shutdown
- Resume previous download but with narrower --select-file, e.g. --select-file=3
- Download at one point reaches 100%, but then goes beyond 100% and is not complete: Neither is the download stopped (or put into seeding mode) nor is it actually complete; there are still pieces missing.

Debian x86_64 on squeeze, aria2 1.15.1 self-built deb (official sources from sf.net; gcc 4.4; using debian/ from official squeeze package source, sans patches)

My guess is that while aria2 shows the actual download size requested, it does in fact download all missing pieces from the previous selection instead of just the pieces from the current selection (e.g. pieces for files #3 and #11 instead of just #3).

title: Add optional flag to specify location of the bash_completion folder location
body:
Hi, I'm the current packager for aria2 for archlinux.

The current behavior for autotools is that the bash_completion directory is hardcoded to install to doc_bashcompletiondir = $(docdir)/bash_completion

When installing, it might be convenient for there to be a flag to specify the location of the bash_completion folder to install the "aria2c" completion file.

The flag could be named --bashcompletiondir and if it is unspecified it would default to $(docdir)/bash_completion and would install the files that are currently installed which are "aria2c" and "README.txt". But if the flag is specified, it would only install the "aria2c" file to the location specified by --bashcompletiondir

This would be especially helpful for packagers by providing a clean interface for them to specify a bash_completion location.

For example, the current location to install bash_completions on archlinux is /usr/share/bash-completion/completions
So the flag would work like:
./configure --bashcompletiondir=/usr/share/bash-completion/completions

This is also a lot cleaner than the current method to install the bash_completion after installing aria2:
  # add bash completion (aria2 automatically installs to a temporary target directory)
  install -d ${pkgdir}/usr/share/bash-completion/completions
  install -m644 ${pkgdir}/usr/share/doc/aria2/bash_completion/aria2c \
    ${pkgdir}/usr/share/bash-completion/completions
  rm -rf ${pkgdir}/usr/share/doc/aria2/bash_completion

title: Some options doesn't work when adding tasks via xml-rpc

Hi,

As far as I've tested, 'allow-overwrite' and 'auto-file-renaming' are not functional when adding tasks via xml-rpc like this:

aria2.addUri(['http://g.cn'], {'allow-overwrite': True, 'auto-file-renaming': False})

I haven't tested other options, which may also have this problem.
